Review Ammonia electrosynthesis on carbon-supported metal single-atom catalysts Mu-Lin Li a Yi-Meng Xie a Jingting Song a Ji Yang a * Jin-Chao Dong a Jian-Feng Li a b * a College of Energy, State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, iChEM, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, Fujian, China College of Energy State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces iChEM College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering College of Physical Science and Technology Xiamen University Xiamen Fujian 361005 China College of Energy, State Key Laboratory of Physical Chemistry of Solid Surfaces, iChEM, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, College of Physical Science and Technology, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, Fujian, China b Innovation Laboratory for Sciences and Technologies of Energy Materials of Fujian Province (IKKEM), Xiamen 361005, Fujian, China Innovation Laboratory for Sciences and Technologies of Energy Materials of Fujian Province (IKKEM) Xiamen Fujian 361005 China Innovation Laboratory for Sciences and Technologies of Energy Materials of Fujian Province (IKKEM), Xiamen 361005, Fujian, China * Corresponding author Ammonia, a feedstock platform for fertilizer and pharmaceutical production, is regarded as a zero-carbon energy carrier. The electrochemical synthesis of ammonia, powered by clean and renewable electricity, has garnered increased attention as an alternative to the Haber-Bosch process. Very recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become highly effective electrocatalysts for such electrochemical transformation, where the isolated metal sites ensure the high atomic utilization efficiency as well as the prevention of nitrogen-nitrogen coupling. In this review, we focus on the recent progress of single-atom catalysts in electrochemical ammonia synthesis and briefly introduce nitrogen cycles in both natural and artificial ecosystems, followed by a discussion of catalyst design by theoretical and experimental methods. Synthesis routes from different nitrogen sources, including dinitrogen (N2) and nitrogen oxides (NO x ), are also highlighted. Besides, the catalysis dynamics as an indispensable section is presented and discussed in-depth. Finally, we tackle challenges and offer perspectives, aspiring to provide insightful guidance for researchers in this community striving for advanced ammonia electrosynthesis. Graphical Abstract This review presents recent advances of single-atom catalysts in ammonia electrosynthesis from different nitrogen-transforming reactions, including dinitrogen reduction, nitrate reduction, nitrite reduction, and nitric oxide reduction. Keywords Ammonia synthesis Nitrogen-transforming reaction Electrochemical reduction Single-atom catalyst Dinitrogen Nitrogen oxides 1 Introduction As one of the highly reactive nitrogen species (RNS), ammonia (NH3) is a crucial platform molecule for the large-scale production of fertilizer, plastics, pharmaceuticals, and other products [1,2]. Besides these chemical industries, NH3 has also been pursued as a promising clean energy carrier due to its high energy density (4.3 kW h kg−1) but environmentally friendly attributes with zero-carbon missions (4NH3 + 3O2 → 2N2 + 6H2O) [3,4]. To date, industrial-scale synthesis of ammonia still relies on the hydrogenation of dinitrogen (N2) through the Haber-Bosch (HB) process, significantly contributing to improved crop yields and a fourfold improvement in the global economy. However, the rapid growth of population and economy in modern society has raised serious concerns about environmental and energy issues, particularly regarding the industrial HB process, which accounts for 2% of global energy demand and results in 3% carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions annually [5,6]. To this end, the proposal of electrochemical hydrogenation of N2 in aqueous electrolytes by mimicking natural enzyme nitrogenases has captured much interest from scientists [7,8]. Operating under mild conditions and powered by renewable energy, the NH3 production from electrochemical N2 reduction reaction (N2RR) presents a promising alternative to the HB process. Such an electroreduction process is thermodynamically evaluated as 20% more energy-efficient than the HB process [9,10]. However, the high dissociation energy (up to 942 kJ mol− 1) and the non-polarizable characteristic of the N2 molecule contribute to its intrinsic inactivity, leading to a diminished NH3 reaction rate [11,12]. In addition to the low production rate, the NH3 generation from N2RR also exhibits an unsatisfactory Faradaic efficiency (FE) due to intense competition with the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [13]. Apart from direct N2 fixation in natural nitrogen cycles, the process involving nitrate and nitrite reductase is another alternative route for NH3 production [14,15]. Unlike the N2 gas, nitrogen oxides (NO x ), usually presented as nitrate (NO3 −), nitrite (NO2 −), and nitric oxide (NO), exhibit lower dissociation energy and higher solubility, making them an ideal nitrogen source for greener NH3 synthesis [16]. Therefore, inspired by natural enzymic catalysis, the conversion of these NO x species to NH3 has been developed as a more feasible pathway for NH3 synthesis. Among various NO x species, electrochemical reduction of nitrate (NO3RR) has emerged as a popular research area [17], achieving an impressive NH3 production rate and selectivity at least one order of magnitude higher than previously reported values of N2RR. In addition to NO3RR, other nitrogen oxide reductions such as NO2 − and gaseous NO (NO2RR and NORR) have also attracted significant attention as possible routes for NH3 generation [18,19]. In recent years, efforts have been directed toward enhancing sustainable NH3 generation by developing more efficient electrocatalysts. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) have emerged as a rapidly growing research focus on heterogeneous nitrogen conversion catalysis [20]. Their inherent advantages, including theoretical 100% atomic utilization and unique coordination structures, enable SACs to achieve superior catalytic activity and selectivity [21], positioning them as a potential alternative to state-of-the-art nanocatalysts. On the other hand, the success of SACs in other electrocatalytic applications, such as the oxygen evolution reaction (OER), oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), has further bolstered scientists’ confidence in the remarkable potential of SACs in the field of electrochemical NH3 synthesis [22]. Therefore, research on single-atom-mediated NH3 production from electrochemical nitrogen-transforming reactions, such as N2RR, NO3RR, NO2RR, and NORR, has proliferated [23], establishing SACs as one of the most extensively studied catalytic materials for NH3 production. In this review, we systematically summarize the development of SACs in NH3 production across various nitrogen-transforming processes, providing insights into recent research advancements. The review begins with a brief introduction to nitrogen cycles in natural and artificial ecosystems. Subsequently, it delves into comprehensive discussions on active site design, encompassing theoretical and experimental perspectives. Then, it highlights the diverse catalysis processes employed for NH3 production. The review also explores catalytic dynamics toward nitrogen conversion reactions with examples, which other reviews do not cover extensively. This review concludes with an enumeration of challenges and perspectives to promote further progress and provide valuable insights for emerging researchers in this field. 2 Brief illustration of nitrogen cycles Nitrogen, a fundamental element in organic and inorganic compounds, plays a vital role in essential synthesis processes for organic fractions, providing a crucial resource for living beings. Understanding the interconversion among the different nitrogen-containing species is imperative, and these transformative processes collectively contribute to the nitrogen cycle, as shown in Fig. 1 [24]. In this section, we first discuss the biogeochemical cycle, which mainly involves five states: (1) biological nitrogen-fixing (labeled as b-1, “b” denotes biological): the conversion of free nitrogen into biologically accessible forms, predominantly ammonium (NH4 +) in our environment; (2) nitrification (labeled as b-2): the conversion of NH3 to nitrite (NO2 −) and nitrate (NO3 −) by distinct nitrifying bacteria, where the negative charged NO x − serves as a critical nitrogen source for assimilation into the organic compound; (3) nitrogen assimilation (labeled as b-3): involving the biosynthesis of amino acids, enzymes, etc., in plants from nitrate in soil; (4) ammonification (labeled as b-4): the decomposition of dead plants and animals by bacteria and fungi, converting their organic nitrogen compound back into NH3/NH4 +; and (5) denitrification (labeled as b-5): the biological conversion of nitrite and nitrate into nitrous oxide or molecular nitrogen. In addition to the biological nitrogen cycles illustrated in Fig. 1, artificial nitrogen cycles involve three key aspects. (1) The Haber process (labeled as a-1, “a” denotes artificial): the recombination of free nitrogen with hydrogen gas in a chamber to produce ammonia under harsh conditions; however, this process requires a large amount of energy and results in massive CO2 emissions. (2) Agriculture (labeled as a-2): the use of ammonia and nitrate as fertilizer to enhance crop yields; however, the excessive application has led to nitrogen loss into water bodies. (3) Animal agriculture (labeled as a-3): the utilization of animal manure as concentrated urea and ammonia sources to support crop growth, potentially causing nitrogen runoff. This discussion underscores those human activities, particularly using nitrogen-containing fertilizers, have significantly supplemented biological nitrogen fixation. However, human-induced alterations to these cycles result in a pronounced imbalance in nitrogen cycles. 3 Fundamental insights toward nitrogen conversion reactions Despite recent advances in NH3 electrosynthesis, further progress in this field has been hampered due to an incomplete understanding of the catalytic reaction mechanisms. This is due to the intricacy of these nitrogen conversion processes, which involve multiple hydrogen-coupled electron transfer steps. Utilizing density functional theory (DFT) as a prediction tool has been widespread for simulating these reaction processes on catalyst surfaces, leading to a recent understanding of these nitrogen-transforming reactions. In this third section, a comprehensive exploration of the underlying mechanisms of NH3 synthesis is undertaken from a theoretical perspective, with the goal of designing and developing highly efficient catalysts. 3.1 N2RR It has been acknowledged in this research area that the NH3 synthesis from N2RR (N2-to-NH3) on heterogeneous active centers mainly follows dissociative and associative mechanisms [8,25,26]. As exhibited in Fig. 2 , the dissociative pathway involves broking the N≡N triple bond to generate two nitrogen atoms on the catalyst surface and hydrogenating and desorbing the adsorbed nitrogen atoms into NH3 molecules. This direct dissociative process is often more energy-intensive, and the industrial HB process is believed to predominantly follow this dissociative mechanism [27]. In contrast, the proposed associative pathway in Fig. 2 gradually breaks the nitrogen-nitrogen triple bond during hydrogenation, making it relatively energy efficient. Depending upon the hydrogenation sequence, this associative pathway includes two alternating and distal approaches. The distinction lies in the heterolytic and homolytic properties of N2 dissociation. In the alternating route, the two nitrogen atoms in the absorbed N2 molecule undergo hydrogenation in sequence. In the associative distal route, hydrogenation preferentially occurs on the terminal nitrogen atom, away from the catalyst surface, while another nitrogen atom on the catalyst surface is further hydrogenated to NH3. As modeled in Fig. 2, the adsorption structure of the N2 molecule in associative pathways exhibits two types: end-on and side-on modes. Therefore, in addition to the discussions above, another reaction pathway emulates the enzymatic process, where the N2 molecule adopts a side-on model followed by alternating hydrogenation to NH3. 3.2 NO3RR The NH3 synthesis process from NO3RR (NO3 −-to-NH3) is more complex, for it involves various nitrogen-related intermediates ranging from +5 to –3 oxidation states, such as NO2 −, NO, N2O, N2, N2H4, and NH3 [28,29]. As depicted in Fig. 3 , NH3 synthesis on the catalyst's surface involves four reaction pathways: O-end, N-side, O-side, and N-end pathways [30]. Additionally, the N2 generation from NO3RR follows the NO-dimer route. In the early reduction stage, the absorbed NO3 undergoes hydrogenation and deoxygenation to NO2 and NO intermediate species. The final products or corresponding reaction paths are influenced by the atomic absorption structure of NO on the catalyst surface [31]. In the O-side absorption, the distal N atom is hydrogenated to NH3, followed by the relaxation of H2O through further hydrogenation. In the N-end pathway, the reaction process follows a reverse sequence, in which the hydrogenation first occurs on the O atom to H2O, leaving the N atom on the catalyst surface and finally hydrogenating to NH3. Regardless of whether the NO species is end-on absorption, the presented side-on models, including N- and O-sides, are essential in this catalytic process. It has been reasonably suggested that this side-on pathway, no matter N or O-side, is more thermodynamically favorable than a side-on process. The N2 formation from NO3RR is also discussed in Fig. 3. In this reaction path, the absorbed NO intermediate species dimerize with the same orientation on the catalyst surface. Protons attack the distal O atoms to form H2O sequentially, and the remaining N atoms are coupled and desorbed to N2 individually. The N2 formation from NO3RR via an N–N coupling process is environmentally friendly; however, the NH3 production is a high-value-added product. 3.3 NO2RR/NORR NH3 synthesis from NO2RR (NO2 −-to-NH3) has been rarely reported in experimental and computational fields, leading to comparatively less attention toward the reaction mechanisms of NO2RR. However, as a primary reaction intermediate in NO3RR, the reduction process of NO2 − is analogous to the latter hydrogenation stage of NO3RR [32]. All five catalytic routes have been proposed concerning NO reduction, as depicted in Fig. 4 [33]. The N atom in adsorbed NO first protonates to *HNO; as a branch, these intermediate produces two pathways based on the different hydrogenated atoms. In pathway 1, the bare O atom is hydrogenated to form *HNOH, likely causing the breakage of the N–O bond. Subsequently, the leaving *NH undergoes successive hydrogenation to form an NH3 product. Regarding pathway 2, the N atom in *HNO serves as an attack site to be hydrogenated, producing *H2NO intermediate that can further undergo hydrogenation to become either *H2NOH (pathway 2) or NH3 and absorbed O (pathway 4). Conversely, hydrogenation on the other O atom produces *NOH, which is further hydrogenated by two different reaction processes. Pathways 3 and 4 involve the hydrogenation of N and O atoms, respectively. Subsequently, the produced *HNOH and *N intermediates undergo successive hydrogenation to form the final NH3. 4 Rational structure design of SACs It is widely acknowledged that reaction performance is mainly dictated by the microenvironment of active sites [34]. Therefore, precisely designing catalytic sites at the atomic scale is essential and represents a research frontier, irrespective of whether catalysis communities are homogeneous or heterogeneous. Leaving their physical characteristics, including single-atom dispersion and an unsaturated coordination structure, SACs have been developed as the most promising catalyst in NH3 formation from various nitrogen-transforming reactions [35]. Hence, the highly efficient avenue to enhance NH3 activity is to precisely regulate the local coordination environments of metal centers in SACs. This fourth section will present the design principle of SACs for different nitrogen-transforming processes from a theoretical perspective, followed by a systematic discussion of experimental catalyst synthesis. 4.1 Catalyst design in view of theory The metal atoms do not merely govern the catalytic functionality in SAC but also rely on the synergy with the ligands incorporated in support [36]. Consequently, the substrate featured with the ability for intense interaction with the metal atoms has been a focal point of consideration. Among various substrates, nitrogen-doped carbon has developed as an emerging material for SACs, attributed to its appropriate cavity size and abundant nitrogen ligands [37]. Therefore, this section employs nitrogen-doped carbon as a substrate for computational predictions. It is important to note that the effective screening of highly active SAC primarily depends on critical evaluation criteria, including (1) structure stability, (2) absorption activation, and (3) reactivity and selectivity. 4.1.1 Structure and stability Considering the tendency of metal atoms to aggregate, the initial screening process involves the evaluation of the most favorable adsorption sites and the thermodynamic stability of the modeling catalysts. Chen et al. [38] identified the monolayer g-C3N4 as an ideal support for depositing single metal atoms and subsequently conducted a computational analysis of the adsorption energies between single metal atoms and ligands. As illustrated in Fig. 5(a) , their theoretical results revealed that the interaction of the six-fold cavity in g-C3N4 with Ti, Mn, Pd, Ag, Au, and W is energetically most intensive. The most favorable anchoring site for other metal atoms is located at the corner of the six-fold cavity. The variation in the anchoring site is attributed to differences in atomic radii and electronegativities. The favorable adsorption energies indicate strong binding between these metal atoms and g-C3N4, suggesting good thermodynamic stability for these predicted SACs. Similarly, Song et al. [39] also assessed the stability of transitional metal (TM) atoms on C3N by calculating their formation energies. They observed that all screened metal centers, including Cr, Mn, Fe, and Co, present negative formation energy values less than –3 eV, indicating high thermodynamic stability of TM atoms on C3N substrates, regardless of the TM-C or N coordination. Additionally, the less-mentioned ab initio molecular dynamics (AMID) simulation was also carried out to further identify structural stability in Fe-C@C3N. The structure of Fe-C@C3N exhibited slight distortion but persisted even after 10 ps at 300 k. This also indicates the high chemical stability of Fe-C@C3N during the synthetic process. In addition to using binding energy (E b) as a descriptor to indicate the thermodynamics of SACs, Choi et al. [13] proposed a practical comparison of E b and E c (cohesive energy) to predict atom stability more accurately. They found that the metal atoms binding with support tend to be thermodynamically stable when the energy sequence is E b > E c. Conversely, metal atoms diffuse on the support and aggregate when E b < E c. As shown in Fig. 5(b), they cross-calculated 30 types of d-block transition metals on different substrates (M@C3, M@C4, M@N3, and M@N4), considering 120 SACs. According to their calculation, almost all SACs exhibited a negative E b value; however, only a portion of modeled catalysts exhibited a negative E b – E c value. 23 M@C3, 26 M@C4, 6 M@N3, and 20 M@N4 were identified as stable without further aggregation. After screening these catalysts, which include 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metals in Fig. 5(c), Deng et al. [40] also confirmed the structure stability of the selected three p-TM[TCNE] (TM = Mo, Nb, and Ti) by calculating the values of E b + E c. They found that the sum valves for Mo-TCNE, Nb-TCNE, and Ti-TCNE are –1.28, –1.95, and –3.10 eV, respectively, showing that these three single atoms on TCNE units form stable active units. The structural stability of SACs towards NO3RR has also been evaluated using the same energy comparisons as those of N2RR. In the study by Sathishkumar et al. [41], 26 TM/g-C3N4 SACs spanning the 3d–5d elemental period were initially theoretically modeled. By calculating the difference between E b and E c, it was observed in Fig. 6(a) that although all SACs demonstrated strong interaction as indicated by negative E b value, only a few, including Sc, Ti, Y, and Hf, exhibited significant negative E b – E c values of –1.79, –0.09, and –0.81 eV, respectively. These values suggest their spontaneous dispersion on g-C3N4 supports. Conversely, calculated E b – E c values for other TM/g-C3N4 SACs showed positive energies, implying a potential risk of clustering on the g-C3N4. Niu et al. [30] (Fig. 6(b)) modeled a series of transition metal single atoms anchored on a g-CN substrate, in which the single metal atom was coordinated via two metal–N bonds. Their results indicated the thermodynamic stability of Ti and Zn single atoms on g-CN supports, as evidenced by their calculated formation energies. In contrast, Ti n or Zr n clusters on g-CN were found to be less stable due to higher formation energies. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 6(c), the kinetic stability of both SACs was confirmed through AIMD simulations, which further suggested that the geometric structures of both SACs remained intact. Lv et al. [42] (Fig. 6(d)) confirm the thermodynamic stability of single atoms on g-C3N4 across the 3d–5d period using the formation energy. As predicted by their calculations, except for the Ta/g-C3N4, all the other TM/g-C3N4 demonstrated good thermodynamic stability. Additionally, electrochemical stability was proposed in their work using the dissolution potential (U diss) as an assessing descriptor. 4.1.2 Adsorption and activation The classical Sabatier principle emphasizes the importance of medium and optimum strength for achieving the best activity for a given reaction; therefore, the adsorption governing the activation of the reactant can act as a descriptor for the specific predictions of new catalysts [43]. In this subsection, the N2 adsorption-free energy change and TM–N and N–N bond lengths are used to evaluate whether N2 is spontaneously adsorbed and effectively activated. N2 chemisorption on single-atom metal centers usually occurs in end-on and side-on geometries. Numerous efforts have been dedicated to identifying the preferred N2 adsorption configuration. For example, based on both proposed adsorption models, Song et al. [39] compare each adsorption energy (E ads), and the corresponding calculations indicate that, as exhibited in Fig. 7(a) , the end-on adsorption by one N atom on the metal center shows more intensive interaction compared to the adsorption of both N atoms. As can be seen, all TMs on C3N, including Cr, Mn, Fe, and Co centers, are suitable candidates for the chemisorption of N2. Among them, the N2 on Mn-C has the strongest adsorption energy of approximately –1.4 eV via an end-on configuration. However, according to the Sabatier rules, some TM/C3N catalysts are predicted to be candidate catalysts due to their most favorable adsorption energy ranging from –1.0 to –0.6 eV. In addition, as seen in Fig. 7(b), the bond length of N2 in the side-on model exceeds 1.17 Å, longer than that in the end-on configuration (1.15 Å), indicating that the N2 adsorption via the side-on model is more conducive to weakening the N–N bond. It has been predicted that much intensive interaction in the side-on configuration results in the limited desorption of the product. Therefore, in most computational examples, the reaction process of N2RR on the catalyst's surface has been predicted via end-on adsorption. As identified by Xue et al. [44] in Fig. 7(c), their calculations also exhibit the same results: the end-on configuration for N2 adsorption is energetically more favorable. In 23 TM@C9N4 catalysts, Pd, Au, Pt, and Ag are excluded due to their positive adsorption energy corresponding to unfavorable adsorption (see the top section in Fig. 7(c)). The rest of the 19 TM@C9N4 catalysts have been predicted as feasible adsorption sites for further activation. Among these candidates, W@C9N4 has the strongest N2 adsorption with an energy value of –1.24 eV. After ΔG N2→*N2 prediction, the activated N≡N bond length by chemisorption for all catalysts has been calculated (see the bottom section in Fig. 7(c)). Among all of them, W and Ta metal centers have the longest bond length of 1.15 Å, making them the most active catalysts for N2 adsorption and further activation. After assessing the feasibility of N2 adsorption-activation, the first protonation of *N2 to *NNH, usually a potential-determining step (PDS) for this reaction, has been further evaluated. As seen in the work by Choi et al. [13], the ΔG PDS of a total of 120 SACs has been calculated, among all of which, only 16 SACs show promising catalytic performance due to the calculation of ΔG PDS < 1 eV in this PDS process (Fig. 7(d)). For the nitrate reduction over SACs, the adsorption structure depends on the adsorption number of oxygen atoms on the metal center, with two commonly considered configurations: one oxygen atom binds to the metal center is η1-O, and two oxygen atoms bind to the metal center is η2-O. After comparisons, Sathishkumar et al. [41] found that NO3 − preferably undergoes η2-O adsorption, where two oxygen coordinate with the metal atoms, which is more energetically favorable than single oxygen coordination. Therefore, the η2-O configuration has been proposed in this research field as a prerequisite for the subsequent reduction process. As seen in Fig. 8(a) , the calculated adsorbed energy of NO3 − on all the catalysts is less than 0 eV, indicating the spontaneous tendency of NO3 − on the catalyst's surface. It should be mentioned that, as shown in Fig. 8(b), the Fe/g-C3N4 and Co-C3N4 catalysts have been eliminated for the chemisorption by Lv et al. [42] due to their positive adsorption energy. In addition to considering adsorption energy, the charge transfer between NO3 − and metal sites has been analyzed by comparing the difference in charge density in TM/g-C3N4. Fig. 8(c) shows that a significant amount of negative charge is transferred from the d-orbital of the central Ru transition metal to the empty p-orbital of the NO3 − species. Moreover, the positively charged TM atoms facilitate the adsorption of intermediates and subsequent reactions. Recent studies have also shown that nitric oxide as a reactant has a strong adsorption capacity and high affinity toward single metal sites. Kong et al. [45] have pioneered work to predict the most active SAC, among which the Ni@GY SAC has been identified as a promising candidate for NO reduction. 4.1.3 Catalytic activity and selectivity Notably, in the process of N2RR, both *N2 → *N2H and *NH2 → *NH3 elemental processes have commonly been proven to be the most plausible PDS. Fig. 9(a) presents a linear scaling relationship of ΔG *NH2→NH3 against ΔG *N2→N2H for 19 TM@C9N4 [44]. As observed, most SACs show a more positive ΔG *N2→*N2H higher than 0.75 eV, predicting that these SACs were ruled out for this first hydrogenation of *N2. The rest of the SACs, such as W, Mo, etc., satisfy the theoretical value of less than 0.75 eV, regardless of the first or sixth hydrogenation step. Therefore, the remaining SACs, such as Ta, Hf, Nb, W, Mo, V, Zr, Ti, Cr, Tc, and Mn, are considered for further consideration. According to Fig. 9(b), the Ta and Hf catalysts have been excluded due to their location in the *H dominant region, resulting in severe HER competition. These remaining SACs are further screened by the calculations of limiting potential U L (= –ΔG max/e), which is widely accepted as an activity descriptor for nitrogen reduction. As shown in Fig. 9(c), W@C9N4, Nb@C9N4, Mo@C9N4, and V@C9N4 are expected to exhibit high N2-to-NH3 activity with their UL of –0.24, –0.36, –0.39, and –0.44 V, respectively. Among these screened catalysts, Ta-based SAC exhibits an unexpected activity for the first elementary step with a much lower ΔG *N2→*N2H of 0.17 eV. In another work, Choi et al. [13] systematically studied the theoretical activity of 120 SACs for N2RR. Among SACs considered in their study, Ti@N4 and V@N4 exhibit a lower limiting potential of –0.69 and –0.87 V, which is comparable and even close to that of previously screened nitride catalysts such as molybdenum nitride nanocluster (–0.8 to –0.5 V), ZrN (–0.76 V), VN (–0.51 V), and RuN (–0.23 V). These 30 types of transition metal atoms embedded in parallel tetracyanoethylene 2D networks have been systematically explored by Deng et al. [40]. Three SACs of Mo, Nb, and Ti are predicted to have high catalytic activity and selectivity for NRR. Among these, the Mo-based catalyst has the highest activity due to its lowest U L of –0.36 V, making it the most promising candidate for NRR. Another computational work by Liu et al. [46] examined activity predictions in more detail by considering the type of metal center and its corresponding coordination environment. In this regard, 60 catalysts, including three categories of SACs covering TM@g-C3N4, TM@N3, and TM@N4, were first modeled by cross-supporting 20 different metal centers on three different types of nitrogen-carbon substrates. Three candidates in the middle of each group of metals present the lowest E L values of –0.61 V for Co@g-C3N4, –0.33 V for Ru@g-C3N4, and –0.65 V for W@g-C3N4. In addition, the Ru@g-C3N4 SAC shows significantly higher N2-to-NH3 activity, even outperforming the well-investigated Ru (0001) surface with a limiting potential of –1.05 V. Recent computational studies have demonstrated that the SACs are highly active and selective catalysts for NO x RR. For instance, Sathishkumar et al. [41] predict that Ti/g-C3N4, V/g-C3N4, and Nb/g-C3N4 are the most promising catalysts for NO3RR due to their outstanding limiting potential of –0.42, –0.25, and –0.40 V, respectively, resulting in excellent stability and activity as well as high selectivity for ammonia production (Fig. 10(a) ). Another computational screening of six types of TM/g-C3N4 for NO3 −-to-NH3 has been examined by Lv et al. [42], as shown in Fig. 10(b), among which Ru/g-C3N4 emerges as the best candidate due to its lowest energy barrier and extraordinary selectivity. The activity origin is further explored and explained in Fig. 10(c) by using NO3 − adsorption energy as an activity descriptor, where a moderate adsorption ability of NO3 − on Ru/g-C3N4 is advantageous for completing the entire reaction. In addition, uncommon metal centers of Zr and Hf supported on g-C2N substrate have been identified as a highly efficient catalyst for NH3 synthesis [41]. Comparing these catalysts of Ti-to-Cu, Zr-to-Ag, expect Tc, and Hf-to-Au, the limiting potentials of Hf and Zr/g-C2N are located at the top of the volcanic curve, with limiting potentials of –0.27 and –0.28 V, respectively. The exploration of other NO x reduction reactions by SACs has been limited, given the highly toxic properties of the human body. However, a recent pioneering work by Niu et al. [47] reports a theoretical prediction of SACs for NO-to-NH3 conversion. The limiting potential and corresponding most favorable NORR pathway indicate that Ti, V, and Zr-C2N are expected to be highly active NO-to-NH3 catalysts. Besides activity evaluation, the NH3 selectivity of three candidates compared to competitive N2, N2O, and H2 evolution has been further assessed. Zr-C2N, in particular, presents a limiting potential sequence of U L(NH3) < U L(H2) < U L(N2) < U L(N2O), indicating that this Zr-C2N catalyst is the most promising candidate for NORR toward NH3. Another first-principles study of SACs for NO reduction reactions was recently reported by Kong et al. [45] They selected graphyne as a substrate for 3d transition metal coordination; among these TM@GY catalysts, Ni@GY exhibited a low limiting potential of –0.51 V, which indicates good catalytic activity. In comparison, the competition of HER is inhibited by the highly positive ΔG *H value of 1.233 eV, demonstrating poor hydrogen production toward Ni@GY. 4.2 Catalyst synthesis In the preceding discussions, the most active SACs for nitrogen conversion reactions were predominantly predicted through high-throughput density functional theory calculations. Nevertheless, from an experimental perspective, the individual metal atoms might migrate and agglomerate on the support due to their high specific surface energy. Therefore, appropriate synthetic procedures are crucial for producing high-quality SACs. This research commonly employs pyrolysis at elevated temperatures for synthesizing SACs. This thermal-reaction process typically involves two simultaneous processes: decomposing selected precursors and generating active metal centers. In this subsection, pyrolysis is discussed based on the different classifications of precursors. 4.2.1 Hybrids of carbon substrate and metal-containing complexes The pyrolysis of metal complexes on a carbon matrix is widely used for synthesizing SACs. In this approach, the metal-containing complex serves as a precursor for the active metal-nitrogen moiety, while the carbon matrix functions as a solid support to disperse the generated active center. As shown in Fig. 11(a) , Chen et al. [48] used carbon black (BP2000) to support and reflux it with the Ag-containing urea complex. Urea, during calcination, typically serves as the source of nitrogen ligand. The combined precursors are then pyrolyzed at 900 °C in an Ar atmosphere to produce Ag-N-C SAC. The determined Ag content in the catalyst is 0.39 wt%. It has been asserted that this hybrid pyrolysis approach, based on commercial carbon support, can prepare SACs beyond the reported Ag-N-C SAC at a large-scale level. Defective graphene oxide (DGO), obtained through nitric acid treatment, was also used by Chen et al. [49] as a solid carbon substrate for supporting and dispersing Fe single-atom centers. As illustrated in Fig. 11(b), thiourea, serving as a bifunctional N/S sources, was ultrasonically dispersed on the DGO substrate. Subsequently, FeCl3·6H2O was added for the chelation, forming dual-coordinated Fe-N/S metal-containing complexes. After thermal treatment at 750 °C for 2 h with the subsequent acid immersion, the resulting Fe-N/S moiety is single-atom dispersed and embedded within the defect graphene lattice. 4.2.2 Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs)-derived strategy Capitalizing on the advantages of well-defined crystalline structure, abundant metal-ligand sites, large surface area, and high chemical tunability, MOF materials have been recognized as a promising precursor for synthesizing SACs [50,51]. Among various MOFs, ZIF-8 is the most widely utilized single-atom precursor through two synthetic strategies: metal node replacement and pore confinement. As exhibited in Fig. 12(a) , Chen and collaborators [52] prepared a Cu-doped ZIF-8 precursor by combining metal nitrate precursors(Cu/Zn salts) with 2-methylimidazole in a methanol solution. The resulting product was then calcined at 950 °C in an inert Ar environment to produce Cu-N-C SAC. In this process, the organic linkers of 2-methylimidazole were thermally converted to an N-doped carbon substrate, and the Zn node was reduced and aggregated, leading to its final evaporation. Meanwhile, the Cu precursor evolved into active single Cu atoms embedded in the N-doped carbon. Notably, the use of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as a metal precursor rather than Cu(Ac)2·H2O indicates the adsorption of the metal node replacement strategy, wherein the target metal replaces the original metal as the new nodes. In addition to the metal mode replacement strategy, pore confinement has been adopted as a generic method for converting metal salt precursors to single atoms. Xu and coworkers [53] added Cu(acac)2 as a single-atom precursor during ZIF-8 crystallization, leading to in-situ encapsulation of Cu(acac)2 in the nano-cavity of ZIF-8. Subsequent heat treatment at 900 °C resulted in the Cu(acac)2 decomposition, and the confinement effect of the voids in ZIF-8 ensured the atomic dispersion of the Cu center in the matrix lattice of N-doped carbon. A similar confinement strategy was utilized by Xu et al. [54], as shown in Fig. 12(b), where triphenylphosphine (PPh3) served as a P source and was trapped in the ZIF-8 cage by mixing PPh3 with ZIF-8 precursors. The slightly larger cavity diameter of 11.6 Å allowed ZIF-8 to encapsulate PPh3 with a molecular diameter of 8.9 Å. Besides the ZIF-based precursor, other MOFs have been used to produce SACs. In Tao's work, Ru-confined UiO-66 was used as MOF precursor and converted to Ru single atoms supported on ZrO2/NC during pyrolysis [55]. 4.2.3 Metal-assisted small molecule pyrolysis Commonly used molecular precursors like citric acid, glucose, melamine, dicyandiamide, and amino acids can serve as carbon or nitrogen sources for synthesizing carbon- or nitrogen-doped substrates. However, these molecular precursors often have low thermal decomposition temperatures, preventing proper carbonization at high pyrolysis temperatures. Incorporating metal species during the pyrolysis of small molecules offers a solution to increase the yield of carbon products. This enhancement is attributed to the strong interaction between metal and ligands in molecular precursors and the metal-catalyzed growth process of graphitic carbon [56]. As such, metal-assisted small-molecule carbonization is a commonly employed method for SAC synthesis. In a study by Liu and coworkers [57] (Fig. 13(a) ), FeCl3, melamine, and L-alanine mixtures served as hybrids of metal salts and small molecules. These hybrids underwent two-stage thermal treatments under an Ar atmosphere: (1) pyrolysis at 550 °C to convert melamine precursor into a C3N4 product and increase the carbon yield of L-alanine, and 2) pyrolysis at an even higher temperature (800, 900, and 1000 °C) to finely control the microenvironment of Fe-N x centers. Similarly, in synthesizing Fe single atoms supported on g-C3N4 (Fig. 13(b)), a mixture of Fe3+ salts and cyanamide was pyrolyzed at 550 °C [58]. This metal-assisted pyrolysis method allows for flexible regulation of the type of doped elements by selecting suitable precursors. For example, introducing carrageenan as a sulfur-containing precursor led to the production of an unusual Fe single atom anchored on N, S-codoped carbon catalyst, as reported by Li and collaborators [59]. In Zhao's work (Fig. 13(c)), 1,10-phenanthroline, a bidentate ligand bound to Cu2+ salt, forms a Cu2+-(phen) supramolecular structure [60]. Thermal treatment at 1000 °C resulted in Cu single atoms embedded in the CN substrate. Furthermore, by mixing Cu2+-(phen) and a boron-containing Cs2[closo-B12H12] precursor followed by calcination, Cu single atoms supported on B-doped CN could also be obtained. 4.2.4 Adsorption-activation strategy This synthetic process for the formation of SACs usually involves two steps. Firstly, there is a chemical chelation phase where metal ions interact with ligands in substrates, such as N/O, P/S, etc. Subsequently, the metal-ligand groups formed in the first step undergo an activation treatment, transforming into active metal centers. In Fig. 14(a) , Yang and coworkers [61] presented a two-step approach for synthesizing Cu-N-C SAC. In this process, Cu2+ ions first bonded to the nitrogen vacancies embedded in N-doped carbon, forming Cu2+-N x moieties. The carbon substrate was derived from the polymerization of 2,6-aminopyridine followed by pyrolysis at NH3/He gases and acid treatment by 10% HF. In the second step, the preformed Cu2+-N x centers converted to Cu-N-C SAC after thermal activation at 800 °C in Ar gas. This adsorption-activation process is mainly governed by the amounts of exposed anchoring sites, such as pyridinic-type nitrogen, in Yang's work. The Cu mass contents reached up to 1.0 wt% due to the abundant pyridinic-nitrogen sites. Similarly, Zhang et al. [62] used a comparable method to obtain an atomically dispersed Fe/Cu catalyst with FeCo as an atom pair embedded in a nitrogen-carbon matrix (Fig. 14(b)). They prepared the holey nitrogen-doped graphene (HNG), where holes resulting from acid oxidation of nitric acid and nitrogen species were introduced through hydrothermal treatments of urea and defect graphene oxide. Nitrogen atoms are substituted with the defective carbon throughout the entire carbon substrate, acting as Fe/Cu salt anchoring sites. Subsequent pyrolysis at inert gas produced Fe/Cu diatom catalysts. N-edge sites in HNG were crucial for synthesizing Fe/Cu catalysts, with metal content at 3.3 wt% and 2.8 wt% for Fe and Cu, respectively. Graphdiyne (GDY), owing to its natural uniform pores and triple bond rich in strong reduction ability, has also been developed as a substrate for SAC synthesis. Feng and collaborators [63] reported the synthesis of Ru single atoms on GDY through a simple adsorption process without further treatment. The GDY/G sandwich substrates were prepared by the Eglinton coupling reaction using the microwave method. Then RuCl3, as a metal precursor, was immobilized on a GDY framework where Ru atoms were coordinated by four carbon atoms and a Cl atom. Besides Ru/GDY, other SACs, such as Co/GDY and Rh/GDY, have also been synthesized [64]. 4.2.5 Sacrificial template-assisted method Silica (SiO2) is commonly used as a hard template in the pyrolysis process to introduce porosity and enhance the carbonization of carbon matrices. High-temperature pyrolysis is followed by removing SiO2 through HF etching, resulting in porous carbon support. Such a porous structure facilitates reactants’ mass transfer and boosts the active centers’ site density. For instance, Li et al. [65] utilized SiO2 NPs as a hard template during the pyrolysis of a mixture containing Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, NH4Cl, and citric acid, at 900 °C. Citric acid served as a carbon precursor and a chelating group to form stable Fe-O moieties. Besides, NH4Cl and SiO2 are used as nitrogen sources and hard templates, respectively. After calcination, the SiO2 template was subjected to HF treatment, generating Fe single atoms on a porous carbon matrix. A similar synthesis process was reported by Wu et al. [66], where mixed precursors, including SiO2 powder, FeCl3, and o-phenylenediamine, were pyrolyzed at 800 °C. Subsequent removal of the SiO2 template by etching with NaOH and H2SO4 produces interconnected vesicle-like structures with well-defined pores in their obtained Fe-N-C catalyst. Using SiO2 as a sacrificial template, other SACs, such as Co and Ni, have also been prepared on a porous carbon substrate. To prevent migration and aggregation of Cu species at high pyrolysis temperature (950 °C), Xue et al. [67] employed SiO2 as a protective shell for Cu species. Such protective pyrolysis allowed highly dispersed Cu single atoms on N-C substrate. The rigid SiO2 layer also chemically etched the outer layer of ZIF-8, creating defects in the form of irregular pores. The subsequent steps involved the adsorption of Cu2+ on the N-C substrate, leading to the generation of Cu-N-C SAC and the final etching process to remove the SiO2 template. 5 Structural identification and catalytic performances From both computational and experimental perspectives, various types of SACs that exhibit activity toward nitrogen conversion reactions have been identified. In recent examples, Fe, Mo, and Ru single atoms have been representatively reported for ammonia electrosynthesis from N2-to-NH3 [68–70]. However, progress in this reaction has faced challenges such as unsatisfactory ammonia performance and nitrogen contamination, leading to stagnation in development. As an alternative, the NO3 −-to-NH3 route has gained attention due to the weakened N-O bond and high solubility of NO3 −. In this context, single atoms across various elements, including Fe, Cu, Co, Mo, etc., have been demonstrated to enhance the ammonia activity and selectivity [15–16,71–72]. In recent reports, other nitrogen-containing contaminants, such as NO2 − and NO, produced from air plasma treatment and flue gas, respectively, have been used as precursors for ammonia electro-generation. Therefore, this subsection will conclude recent advances in SACs for NH3 electrosynthesis, and corresponding activity comparisons will be presented in Tables 1–3 . 5.1 SACs for N2RR In this synthetic route of converting N2-to-NH3, SACs play a crucial role in weakening the bond strength of N≡N, thereby activating the triple bond. In this process, the transitional metal center interacts with molecular N2, accepting the lone pair electrons of N2 and providing electrons into the antibonding orbital of N2 [73]. Such interaction leads to the activation of the N≡N triple bond. SACs, owing to the ensemble effect for hydrogen production, exhibit improved NH3 selectivity and reduced HER activity compared to bulk or nanomaterials [13]. Additionally, the strong interactions between transitional metal and support ligands at the single-atom interface not only strengthen the chemical stability of the metal-ligand moiety but also contribute to improved catalytic durability during catalysis. In recent years, transitional-metal single atoms, including precious and non-precious metals, have been proposed as effective N2RR catalysts and have demonstrated exciting NH3 performance regarding production rate, FE, and stability. Ruthenium (Ru) single atoms have been identified as promising electrocatalysts for ammonia synthesis at ambient conditions, demonstrating a smaller barrier toward N2 activation than flat Ru (0001) and other precious metal materials [74]. Geng and coworkers [70] developed a Ru SAC supported on nitrogen-doped carbon (Ru SAs/N-C) by pyrolyzing the Ru-confined ZIF-8 precursor. Structural characterizations, including HAADF-STEM and XAFS, confirmed single-atom dispersion of Ru and its coordination with 3–4 nitrogen atoms (Figs. 15(a) and (b) ). The Ru single atoms exhibited remarkable electrocatalytic activity for N2-to-NH3 conversion, with a record high production rate of 120.9 μgNH3 h−1 mg−1 cat. and a FE of 29.6%, at the working potential of –0.2 V vs. RHE (Figs. 15(c) and (d)). In comparison, Ru nanoparticles (NPs) prepared for reference showed significantly lower catalytic activity for NH3 synthesis. Analysis of N2 temperature-programmed desorption profiles and theoretical calculations suggested that N2 on Ru single atoms had stronger adsorption and more negative free energy in the steps of *N2 to *NNH compared to Ru NPs. In this context, the developed Ru SAs/N-C has proven to be highly efficient catalysts for NH3 electrosynthesis from N2. Beyond the positive role of Ru centers in N2 electroreduction, the substrate, influenced by the coordination environment, structure homogeneity, and site accessibility, has also been demonstrated to enhance NH3 activity. In Tao's work, Ru single atoms supported on ZrO2/NC were prepared by coordinating with the NH2 group in UiO-66 precursor followed by pyrolysis [55]. Activity comparisons in Figs. 15(e) and (f) show that the presence of –NH2 ligands and ZrO2 significantly improved the catalytic activity and suppressed the competitive hydrogen gas production over atomic Ru sites, affording a high production rate of 3.665 mgNH3 h−1 mg−1 Ru with an impressive FE of 21% at –0.21 V vs. RHE. Contrary to Ru single atoms, the Ru nanocatalysts, either commercial 5% Ru/C or NaBH4-reduced Ru NPs, exhibit nearly zero FE due to the predominant occurrence of HER over aggregated Ru sites. To elucidate the promoting effect of ZrO2 and nitrogen-doped carbon, two atomic models of Ru@Zr32O63 and Ru/NC2 were screened and showed improved NH3 performance. As indicated in Fig. 15(g), compared to Ru (0001), these Ru SACs decrease the free-energy change in the most energy-consuming step of *N2 to *NNH, typically a PDS for N2-to-NH3. Meanwhile, hydrogen adsorption on Ru@Zr32O63 was predicted to be suppressed, indicating high selectivity for the N2-to-NH3 route. Anticipating the support of Ru SACs by nitrogen-doped carbon, Feng et al. [63] developed Ru single atoms anchored on a graphdiyne substrate using a simple impregnation strategy. HAADF-STEM images confirm the single-atom dispersion of Ru, and the EXAFS characterization revealed that the Ru atoms were coordinated by four N atoms and a Cl atom. The as-synthesized Ru SAs/GDY/G exhibited high mass activity of 4.7 mgNH3 h−1 mgRu −1 with a remarkably high FE up to 37.6% for NH3 synthesis at the low applied potential of –0.1 V vs. RHE (Figs. 15(h) and (i)). These performance metrics exceeded most previously reported results. In this catalytic system, GDY was a hydrogen adsorption site to produce active hydrogen radicals, which further attacked the adsorbed N2 on Ru sites to produce *NNH intermediate species. The dual-active sites in Ru SAs/GDY/G contributed to high NH3 activity and selectivity, outperforming those of Ru NPs/G. Another example by Zou and collaborators reported that the graphdiyne-supported Rh single atoms achieved a record-high NH3 performance in a pressurized reaction system, with an FE of 20.36% and a formation rate up to 74.15 μg h−1 cm−2, respectively [64]. In addition to Ru/Rh SACs, coin-metal catalysts like Au and Ag have been extensively investigated for NH3 production. Wang and colleagues achieved NH3 electrosynthesis using Au single atom in N2 electroreduction [75]. The Au single atoms supported on g-C3N4 were synthesized by a simple adsorption-activation method, and the atomic local environment was determined with three nitrogen coordination (Fig. 16(a) ). This Au-N3 moiety exhibited a high NH3 FE of 11.1% in 5 mmol L−1 H2SO4 electrolyte at –0.1 V vs. RHE, with the corresponding NH3 production rate reaching 1350 μg h−1 mgAu −1. This rate was approximately 22.5 times that of Au NPs (Figs. 16(b) and (c)). DFT calculations suggested that the PDS of *N2 to *NNH over Au1/C3N4 consumed a smaller free energy change compared to that of Au (211), indicating the predominant occurrence of NH3 synthesis over Au single atoms rather than Au NPs (Fig. 16(d)). Another work by Qin et al. [76] also reported the promoting role of Au single atoms in electrochemical N2-to-NH3. They found that Au single atoms supported on N-doped porous carbon (Au SAs-NDPCs) showed excellent performance, with the yield rate and FE of NH3 being 2.32 μg h−1 cm−2 and 12.3%, respectively. This superior catalytic activity is mainly governed by Au centers and partly attributed to NDPCs with a larger surface area and highly open porous structures, facilitating mass transport of reactants and improving the accessibility of active sites during N2RR. Besides Au SACs, Ag single atoms embedded in nitrogen-doped carbon (SA-Ag/NC) have been explored for NH3 electrosynthesis by Chen and coworkers [48]. SA-Ag/NC was obtained through a sacrificial template-assisted method, and structural characterizations confirmed the atomic dispersion of Ag with an Ag-N4 microenvironment embedded in a nitrogen-doped carbon matrix (Fig. 16(f)). A record-high NH3 yield rate and desirable FE were achieved over Ag-N4 centers in N2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 HCl solution, reaching up to 69.4 mg h−1 mgAg −1 at –0.65 V vs. RHE and 21.9% at –0.60 V vs. RHE, respectively (Fig. 16(g)). Meanwhile, this as-prepared Ag-N4 moiety retained a stable NH3 production rate and reduction current density over 20 consecutive catalytic cycles and even 60 h of electrolysis, respectively (Figs. 16(h) and (i)). Due to the scarcity and high cost of precious transitional metals, non-precious transitional metals such as Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Mo have been employed as active catalysts for N2-to-NH3 reduction [77]. Among these reported catalysts, Fe SACs have been extensively explored, mimicking the Fe component in biological organisms. Wang and collaborators [68] developed Fe single atoms anchored on a nitrogen-doped carbon matrix by pyrolyzing polypyrrole-iron coordination complex. Combined electron microscope and spectral characterizations confirmed the presence of atomically dispersed Fe species with a coordination form of Fe-N4 anchored on carbon support (Figs. 17(a) and (b) ). In comparison to pure N-C support tested in a 0.1 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte, this Fe-N4 moiety not only presented a positive-shift onset potential of 0.193 V vs. RHE but also delivered a record high FE of up to 56.55% as well as a production rate of 7.48 μg h−1 mg−1 at 0 V vs. RHE, clearly indicating its promoting effect toward N2RR (Figs. 17(c) and (d)). Additionally, the onset potential and FE of FeSA-N-C reported in Wang's work also outperformed those of most recently reported SACs. According to molecular dynamics (MD) studies, the tiny energy barrier of N2 access to Fe sites, N2 molecules allows N2 molecules to accumulate on the catalyst surface, facilitating N2 adsorption with further hydrogenation and promoting catalytic activity (Fig. 17(e)). Notably, the preferable adsorption of N2 predicted by DFT calculations also hindered the hydrogen adsorption, resulting in suppressed HER during N2RR (Fig. 17(f)). Notably, the Fe atoms’ microenvironments significantly influence their electronic structures, thereby regulating the NH3 catalytic activity. Li et al. [65] developed a N/O multi-coordinated Fe SAC by calcining mixed precursors of SiO2, Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, NH4Cl, and citric acid, where NH4Cl and citric acid served as nitrogen and oxygen sources, respectively. In addition, using SiO2 as a template during the synthetic process of FeSA-NO-C-900 can offer the SAC a hierarchical porous structure and a larger Biunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area compared to the non-SiO2-templated one. Such structure maximized the Fe site density and facilitated the mass transport of N2 molecules during the reaction. The fine structure of Fe centers has been analyzed, revealing the coordination of four oxygen atoms and two nitrogen atoms, in which two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms were in the plane of the carbon matrix, and the other two oxygen atoms adsorbed Fe atoms in the out-of-plane. Consequently, this heteroatom-coordinated Fe-N2O4 moiety exhibited a remarkable catalytic yield of 31.9 μgNH3 h−1 mg−1 cat.. At –0.4 V vs. RHE in an N2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 HCl solution, a high NH3 FE reached 11.8%. In comparison, the only nitrogen-coordinated Fe centers in FeSA-NO-C-900-H2 exhibited significantly lower NH3 selectivity, indicating the positive effect of oxygen coordination in promoting the reduction activity of N2-to-NH3. In addition, the theoretical predictions further suggested that introducing the O atom dramatically decreased the energy barrier of *N2-to*NNH (PDS), therefore enhancing NRR activity. In addition to oxygen coordination, sulfur (S) has been widely used to regulate the microenvironment of transitional metal single atoms. In another work by Li et al. [59], S was introduced to produce N,S-coordinated Fe SACs anchored on a carbon substrate by pyrolyzing small molecule precursors containing carrageenan, urea, and iron nitrate, followed by acid washing to remove impurities. As shown in Fig. 18(a) , combined structure examinations revealed that Fe was ligated to one sulfur and three nitrogen atoms, and it was further identified that the introduction of S induced the transition of spin-polarization configuration, leading to the formation of a medium-spin-state of Fe (t2g6 eg1). Therefore, the newly synthesized Fe SAC, tested in N2-bubbled 0.1 mol L−1 HCl solution, exhibited prominent catalytic activity with a yield rate of 30.4 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. And FE of 21.9%, respectively (Fig. 18(b)). Meanwhile, the activity measurements in the flow cell also yielded a record-high current density of up to 10 mA cm−2, together with 10% NH3 FE. Such excellent activity is attributed to the adsorbed N–N bond on the FeN3S1, accelerating the N2 activation on the catalyst surface. Furthermore, the reductive protonation of *N2-to-*NNH over FeN3S1, which is typically the PDS during N2RR, exhibited a smaller energy barrier of 0.46 eV than this step for FeN4 (0.99 eV), suggesting that the S coordination indeed lowered the free energy barrier, thus promoting the intrinsic NH3 activity (Fig. 18(c)). Such enhanced NH3 performance by the introduction of S was further reported by Chen's work, where the synthesized Fe-N3S catalyst exhibited strong activity with a high NH3 yield rate of 28.89 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. at –0.4 V vs. RHE and FE of 23.7% at –0.1 V vs. RHE, respectively [49]. In addition to the previous discussion about Fe SACs, Zang and coworkers [78] reported an example of Cu SAC as an efficient electrocatalyst for NH3 production. Cu single atoms anchored in porous nitrogen-doped carbon were produced using g-C3N4 to support further carbonization. The atomically dispersed Cu atoms with mixed coordination structures of Cu-N2 and Cu-N4 were demonstrated by HAADF-STEM and EXAFS characterizations, respectively (Figs. 19(a) and (b) ). Consequently, this Cu SAC exhibited highly efficient pH-universal NH3 performance with a yield rate of 53.3 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. and FE of 13.8% under 0.1 mol L−1 KOH, as well as a yield of 49.3 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. yield rate and an FE of 11.7% in 0.1 mol L−1 HCl, respectively (Figs. 19(c) and (d)). From an experimental perspective, such catalytic activity is ascribed to a high density of active Cu sites and abundant porosity throughout the carbon substrate. Computational predictions further supported the unsaturated Cu-N2 configuration as an active center promoting N2 reduction via an energetically favorable alternating reaction pathway. Mukherjee et al. [79] developed an active Ni SAC for NH3 electrosynthesis. They found that the obtained Ni-N3 center, produced from pyrolyzing Ni-contained MOF precursor at 700 °C, afforded a superior catalytic performance with an NH3 yield rate of 115 μg h−1 cm−2 at –0.8 V vs. RHE and high Faradaic efficiency up to ca. 21% at –0.2 V vs. RHE. This experimentally observed activity was corroborated by DFT calculations, wherein the entire reaction pathways involving N2 adsorption, hydrogenation, and final desorption were found to be thermodynamically favorable over Ni-N3 sites at an electrode potential of –0.79 V. In Han's work, Mn single atoms were also demonstrated to be active for NH3 production from electrochemical N2RR [80]. Notably, the atomic structure of Mn-O3N1 anchored on porous carbon has been finely identified by comparing theoretical and experimental XANES spectra. As such, the hetero-coordinated Mn-O3N1 moiety yielded a high NH3 generation rate of 66.41 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. in N2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 HCl solution at –0.35 V vs. RHE, which is four times higher than on the controlled Mn-N4 sample. In another work by Han's group, they further developed an atomically dispersed Mo catalyst for efficient NH3 synthesis, inspired by the Mo-based structure of the natural enzyme nitrogenase [69]. These Mo single atoms were electrolyzed in an N2-saturated 0.1 mol L−1 KOH solution at –0.3 V vs. RHE and achieved a superior NH3 yield rate of 34 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., with a correspondingly high FE of up to 14.6% (Fig. 19(e)). In addition, Mo single atoms embedded in porous nitrogen-doped carbon also showed better catalysis durability with a stable FE ranging from 6.1% to 7.2%, even after 50000 s electrolysis in 0.1 mol L−1 HCl electrolyte (Fig. 19(f)). 5.2 SACs for NO3RR Though various catalysts have been explored for NH3 formation from electrochemical N2 reduction, intrinsic issues in this reaction, like low selectivity competed by HER and nitrogen contamination, have seriously impeded its further development. Due to its wide existence in surface water and underground aquifers in recent years, NO3 − has been used as the nitrogen source for NH3 production via this reduction route of NO3 −-to-NH3 [81,82]. Some progress has been made based on transitional metal single-atom catalysts, in which the NH3 FE from NO3RR reaches and even exceeds 90%, far outperforming the 40% FE reported in N2-to-NH3 [83]. At present, carbon-supported Cu single atoms are the most explored materials and exhibit good activity and selectivity for NO3 −-to-NH3. For instance, Chen et al. [84] developed twenty types of metal single atoms supported on solid 3,4,9,10-perylenetetracarboxylic dianhydride (M-PTCDA) for highly efficient reduction of NO3 −-to-NH3 and experimentally screened out Cu single atoms as the most active catalyst (Fig. 20(a) ). As a result, the Cu-PTCDA material achieved an impressive NH3 FE of 77% with a high production rate of approximately 436 μgNH3 h−1 cm−2 at –0.4 V vs. RHE in 0.1 mol L−1 PBS containing NO3 − electrolytes, both of which are at least one order of magnitude higher than the previously reported values of N2-to-NH3 (Figs. 20(b) and (c)). From the computational perspective, the stronger adsorption of NO3 and more negative Gibbs energy of H2 production on Cu-PTCDA also support the prediction of high NH3 activity and suppress HER processes (Figs. 20(d) and (e)). This example by Chen et al. is a pioneering work that confirms Cu single atoms as active catalysts for NO3RR. However, Cu-PTCDA-catalyzed NO3RR resulted in the accumulation of toxic NO2 − products and led to catalyst deactivation during long-term electrolysis. Therefore, Cu single atoms confined in pyrolyzed nitrogen-doped carbon would be a promising catalyst for the highly efficient reduction of NO3 −-to-NH3. According to Chen's work, Cu-N-C was synthesized by pyrolyzing Cu-containing ZIF-8 precursors at 950 °C. Structure examinations exhibited atomically dispersed Cu species confined by four nitrogen coordination in the carbon lattice [52]. This measured Cu-N-C in 50 mg L−1 NO3 −-containing 0.5 mol L−1 Na2SO4 delivered 94% NH3 selectivity and a production rate of 9.23 mg h−1 mg−1 cat.. In particular, the concerned NO2 − product was dramatically alleviated on this pyrolyzed Cu-N-C, and the corresponding active structure persisted even after durability measurements. This suppression effect of Cu SAC toward NO2 − generation was further demonstrated in Zhu's work, in which the pyrolysis-produced Cu-N-C-800 exhibited a much lower NO2 − content than that of Cu NPs and plate [85]. The promoting effect of the coordination environment toward NH3 activity and selectivity was further explored on single-atom Cu sites. In Xue's example, Cu single atoms anchored on micro- or mesoporous nitrogen-doped carbon frameworks were synthesized, and the atomic environments corresponding to hetero-coordinated Cu-N3C1 were identified by XANES calculations and EXAFS characterizations (Fig. 21(a) ) [67]. Benefitting from the one C substitution to a nitrogen atom, DFT calculations showed the electron density would be more localization around Cu-N3C1 moieties compared with Cu-N4 sites (Fig. 21(b)), and thus resulted in the reduction of activation barrier in these steps of *HNO3→*NO2 and *NH2→*NH3 (Fig. 21(c)). Besides, the stronger NO3 − adsorption and higher energy barrier for H2 evolution also suggested the predominant occurrence of NO3 − hydrogenation and suppressed HER, respectively. As such, the explored Cu-N3C1 single-atom centers were tested in a 50 mL Na2SO4 solution containing 100 mg-N mL−1 NaNO3 and hence produced a high NH3 yield rate of 5466 mmol h−1 g−1 Cu with a high transformed efficiency of up to 94.8% (Fig. 21(d)). In addition to the carbon substitution, oxygen as hetero-coordinated ligands for Cu centers has been recently reported by Cheng and collaborators [86]. In their work, two groups of Cu-N2O2 moieties within trans- and cis-configurations were first modeled for the activity prediction of NO3 −-to-NH3, with Cu-N4 structure as a comparison. Computational results from MD simulations suggested that similar to Cu-N4, the localization of NO3 − predominantly occurred at both Cu-cis-N2O2 and Cu-trans-N2O2, indicating clearly that the O side has a promoting effect for NO3 − accumulation on the catalyst surface and thus significantly improves catalytic efficiency. Among the two examined Cu-N2O2 catalysts, DFT calculations further screened the cis configuration as the most active site for NH3 synthesis. According to the theoretical predictions, cis Cu-N2O2 SACs were designed by calcinating 1D organic-inorganic chains containing precise cis N2O2 ligands as substrates. As a result, the remaining cis Cu-N2O2 catalyst achieved an average reaction rate of 27.84 mgNH3 h−1 cm−2 at an industrial-level current density of 366 mA cm−2. Even after operation for more than 2000 h, the catalytic activity and long-term stability of cis Cu-N2O2 were well preserved. As expected from the studies of hetero-coordinated atoms, Liu and coworkers [87] also demonstrated that the different N coordination types significantly affect the catalytic activity of Cu single atoms toward NO3RR. They found that the Cu-pyridinic-N4 single atoms delivered a much higher NH3 catalytic performance with 94.61% FE and a 130.71 mg h−1 mg−1 Cu rate. Another example of the discussion of the microenvironment effect is reported in Zhao's work, in which the B doping in BCN-Cu SAC enhanced the catalytic production of NH3 from the reduction of NO3 − [60]. Apart from Cu SACs, N-coordinated Fe single atoms were also developed as active sites for NO3RR. Li et al. [88] designed a Fe SAC by pyrolysis of Fe-containing polymer-hydrogel at 800 °C with subsequent acid treatment of 0.5 mol L−1 H2SO4. These obtained Fe single atoms were characterized and exhibited a FeN4 coordination structure embedded in the nitrogen-doped carbon matrix (Figs. 22(a) and (b) ). After being tested in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH containing 0.1 mol L−1 KNO3 electrolyte, the Fe single atoms presented a positive-shift onset potential of 0.3 V vs. RHE and delivered a maximum NH3 production rate of 2.75 mg h−1 cm−2 with nearly 100% FE (Figs. 22(c)–(e)). One interesting finding is that HER was almost suppressed, and the worried NO2 − accumulation in bulk solution was dramatically reduced in this Fe single-atom mediated catalytic system. In contrast, Fe NPs with a diameter of 30–50 nm exhibited a lower FE of only 80% for NH3 production due to the intense competition from HER. Theoretical investigations indicated all the deoxygenation and hydrogenation steps were energy-favorable on Fe single-atom sites, aside from the final NH3 desorption step. Another work from Wu et al. [66] employed three types of SACs: Fe, Co, and Ni SACs synthesized from a sacrificial SiO2 template-assisted method. In this method, metal salts, o-phenylenediamine, and SiO2 powder were pyrolyzed, followed by etching treatments to remove the template and possible metallic NPs (Fig. 22(f)). Among these SACs, Fe single atoms were identified as the most active catalyst for reducing NO3 −-to-NH3. Specifically, as illustrated in Figs. 22(g)–(h), the Fe SAC in 0.1 mol L−1 KNO3/0.25 mol L−1 K2SO4 mixed solutions exhibited highly efficient NH3 performance with a FE of 75% and a yield rate up to 20000 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., surpassing the tested activities of controlled samples, including Co SAC, Ni SAC, and Fe NPs (Fig. 22(i)). One noteworthy result is that, unlike the 20% dissolution of Fe NPs during NO3 − electrolysis, active FeN4 moieties supported on porous nitrogen-doped carbon retained stable, with no detected dissolved Fe species, suggesting the high stability of Fe active sites. Another work by Song and coworkers [58] also demonstrated the catalytic activity of Fe single atoms toward the NO3RR. The coordination environments of the Fe single-atom center have also been modified to improve the NH3 performance. In Liu's research work, various coordination structures of Fe centers on nitrogen-doped carbon support were achieved by pyrolyzing Fe-containing precursors at different temperatures [57]. Structure examinations showed that the temperature-dependent structures of Fe centers correspond to O-Fe-N4 at 800 °C, Fe-N3 at 900 °C, and Fe-N4 at 1000 °C, respectively. Among these resulting Fe single atoms, Fe1/N-C-900 exhibited the highest NO3RR performance, with an NH3 yield rate of up to 18.8 mgNH3 h−1 mg−1 cat. at –0.9 V vs. RHE and 86% FE at –0.7 V vs. RHE. This indicates that the corresponding Fe-N3 structure is responsible for much higher catalytic activity. Operando electrochemical attenuated total reflection surface-enhanced infrared absorptive spectroscopy (ATR-SEIRAS) further confirmed the NO3RR mechanisms over Fe-N3 sites, involving deoxygenation of *NO3 → *NO2 → *NO → *N and hydrogenation of *N → *NH → *NH2 → *NH3. Among the entire reaction steps, the protonation of *NO to *HNO as a PDS on the Fe-N3 model has the lowest energy barrier of 0.26 eV, further supporting the highest catalytic performance as predicted by DFT. N and P co-coordination with Fe single atoms offers another approach for active site microenvironment regulation, as demonstrated by Xu's group [54]. They observed that P doping as a coordinate significantly enhanced the NO3RR performance. In comparison, Fe-N/P-C SAC achieved a 90.3% FE with a yield rate of 17980 μg h−1 mg−1 cat., much higher than the N-coordinated Fe-N-C catalyst. Theoretical calculations indicated that the FeN3P1O1 structure has a lower energy barrier of 0.26 eV, corresponding to the transformation of *NO to *NOH, compared to that of FeN4 (0.31 eV). This suggests the positive role of P substitution in promoting NH3 activity. 5.3 SACs for NO2/NORR NO2 − and NO, two primary components of NO x , have also become an appealing alternative for NH3 synthesis [89,90]. However, to our knowledge, only several examples of SAC have been developed for the electrochemical reduction of NO2 −-to-NH3 or NO-to-NH3. For instance, Murphy and coworkers demonstrated Fe and Co-N-C SACs achieve 100% NH3 FE from the reduction of NO2 − after experimentally screening fourteen types of M-N-C catalysts covering 3d-, 4d-, 5d-, and f-block transitional metals (Fig. 23 ) [91]. In addition to the reported non-precious transitional metals, precious metals corresponding to Ru single atoms exhibited highly efficient performance for the transition of NO2 −-to-NH3 [92]. The Ru single atoms were synthesized by the pyrolysis of the Ru-containing ZIF-8 precursor at 1000 °C with subsequent acid treatment to remove the existing metal NPs. The produced Ru single atoms, tested in 1 mol L−1 KOH with 0.5 mol L−1 NO2 − electrolyte, gave a 97.8% NH3 FE at –0.4 V vs. RHE, which is a much higher value than that of NO3RR (maximum 72.8% at –0.6 V vs. RHE). This indicates that reducing NO2 −-to-NH3 other than NO3RR is preferable for NH3 synthesis. In contrast, Ru NPs exhibited a significantly lower FE of 57.8% at –0.25 V vs. RHE, further revealing the superior NH3 selectivity on Ru single atoms. Concerning NORR, Nb single atoms were first proposed as catalytically active sites for NH3 production in Peng's work [93]. This Nb catalyst was obtained by pyrolyzing a mixture of Nb salt, polyethylene glycol, urea, boric acid, and melamine foam. Structure characterizations suggested the Nb species are atomically dispersed with an N2B2 coordination structure on a carbon substrate. The as-synthesized Nb-N2B2 SAC achieved a record-high NH3 formation rate of 8.2 × 10−8 mol cm−2 s−1 at –0.6 V vs. RHE (Figs. 24(a)–(c) ). In comparison, other samples produced by the same synthetic method, including Al, Mn, Fe, and Cu SACs, exhibited lower catalytic activity, indicating the significance of Nb sites in NORR. Zhang and coworkers [94] obtained a Ce SAC confined in nitrogen-doped hollow carbon spheres, which allows NO reduction to NH3 in acidic conditions with a maximal 91% FE and corresponding yield rate up to 1023 μg h−1 mg−1 cat. at –0.7 V vs. RHE (Fig. 24(d)). Ce nanoclusters, in contrast, exhibited an inferior FE and lower production rate for NH3 production, implying the highly catalytic activity of Ce single atoms for NORR. Furthermore, Zhao and collaborators [95] designed three types of metalloporphyrin covalent framework supported on graphene using the Glaser-Eglinton coupling reaction, where the metal centers correspond to Fe, Co, and Ni, respectively. Taking advantage of the homogeneous substrate, the three SACs produced have a well-defined atomic structure with four pyrrolic nitrogen coordination. Among these SACs measured in NO-saturated 0.5 mol L−1 K2SO4 solution, NiN4 sites preferably produced NH3 with a high yield rate of 1.6 mmol h−1 mg−1, whereas FeN4 centers showed high selectivity toward the NH2OH product, achieving a high selectivity of 83.5% with a record high reaction rate of 3.1 mmol h−1 mg−1. 6 Structure evolution during nitrogen conversion reactions Catalytic dynamics play a pivotal role in reaction processes, influenced by both external electric/thermal fields and adsorption/desorption of reaction intermediates [96,97]. Recent breakthroughs in advancing NH3 synthesis from nitrogen-transforming reactions involve potential-driven structural reconfiguration. For instance, Yang and coworkers [61] revealed a reversible dynamic transformation between Cu single atoms and NPs during NO3RR. This makes a pioneering exploration that reveals evolved Cu NPs as real active sites for the electroreduction of NO3 −-to-NH3, challenging the conventional understanding based on the Cu-N-C catalyst, where the single Cu sites only serve as a precursor. In detail, the Cu-N4 initially transformed into an unsaturated Cu-N3 structure with one nitrogen ligand dissociation at 0.0 V vs. RHE during NO3RR. Notably, the dynamic behavior of Cu-N4 transitioning to Cu-N3 was also evident during the electrolysis of H2O without NO3RR, emphasizing that Cu-N3 is a potential-driven intermediate. Upon the further reduction at negative potentials, Cu-N3 evolved into the aggregated Cu NPs. The oxide state of Cu-N-C in NO3RR showcased a gradual transition from Cu2+ to Cu+ and eventually to Cu0 (Figs. 25(a) and (b) ), highlighting the dynamic evolution. In contrast, Cu single atoms applied in 0.1 mol L−1 KOH solution exhibited a lighter reconfiguration with much fewer Cu aggregation, suggesting the promoting effect of nitrogen-containing intermediates (Fig. 25(c)). Among these evolved Cu structures, Cu0 NPs emerged as genuine active sites for NH3 formation from NO3RR. Additionally, dynamic dispersion of single atoms from Cu NPs was also observed by in-situ XAFS and identical-location electron microscopy, highlighting the intricate dynamic behavior of Cu single atoms evolving into NPs during NO3RR (Figs. 25(d) and (e)), which was also reported by Xu and Ji [98,99]. Moreover, the intricate dynamics of Fe single atom centers during NO3RR can be tracked using SI-SECM tests. Li et al. [88] found that the Fe(III)-N x sites in their SAC underwent an initial reduction to Fe(II)-N x at working potentials ranging from 0.8–0.9 V vs. RHE, followed by a transformation to Fe(0)-N x occurred at potentials below 0.1 V vs. RHE. The concurrent alterations in the Fe(0)-N x structure and NH3 activity with applied potentials strongly suggested the catalytic activity of Fe(0)-N x during NO3RR. However, the exact coordination structures of Fe centers were not conclusively determined by SI-SECM. In practice, real-time monitoring of such dynamic changes in Fe coordination during reaction processes was accessible through in-situ EXAFS spectra [100]. In Yang's example, the initial FeSAO4(OH)1a structure exhibited potential-driven dynamics. Specifically, it transformed into FeSAO4(OH)1a′(OH)1b at open circuit potential and further evolved into FeSAO3(OH)1a″ through the detachment of one oxygen ligand during N2RR. These in-situ generated unsaturated Fe centers were demonstrated to facilitate highly efficient N2 to NH3 conversion catalysis. 7 Conclusions and perspectives The synthesis of NH3 through the electroreduction of N2 or NO x has rapidly gained attention as a dynamic research area; notable strides have been achieved with SACs to enhance catalytic performance and unravel fundamental mechanisms. This review delves into recent progress within a comprehensive framework, covering nitrogen cycles, reaction mechanisms, structure design through theory and experiments, performance evaluation, and structure dynamics. Addressing concerns about imbalanced nitrogen emissions from human activities in nitrogen cycles, inspiration has been drawn from nitrogen conversions in biological processes to fabricate highly efficient catalysts. Exploring NH3 synthesis from diverse nitrogen-transforming reactions has provided insight into reaction mechanisms at the catalyst surface and paved the way for the design and optimization of promising catalysts. Computational predictions have identified various catalytically active sites for NH3 production, including Mn, Fe, Co, etc. Fe and Ru single atoms supported on nitrogen-doped carbon emerged as some of the most active SACs for N2RR. However, challenges such as low selectivity, limited yield rates, and pervasive nitrogen contamination have hindered SACs’ advancement in this reaction. In contrast, the conversion of NO x into NH3 holds promise due to its higher production rate and selectivity. Among the currently reported SACs for NO x RR, Fe and Cu SACs stand out as widely used and highly effective. Recent progress highlights structure evolution during the reaction process, shedding light on dynamic aspects contributing to catalytic efficiency. In reflecting on the recent strides highlighted in this review, several perspectives have been outlined to advance nitrogen conversion reactions, aiming for heightened catalytic activity and providing fundamental insights to guide future research. (1) Computational precision: the current identification of active sites and catalytic mechanisms primarily occurs through static calculations, comparing adsorption and free energy in vacuum conditions. However, the intricate processes of proton and electron transfers during NH3 synthesis and structural evolution in real reactions pose challenges for precise and reliable explanations. To address this, MD calculations, recognized as an emerging and potent tool for dynamic predictions, should be harnessed. Their use can guide the precise design of SACs and deepen our fundamental understanding of catalytic mechanisms. (2) Ensemble catalyst design: while transitional metal single atoms exhibit promise, the intricate nature of catalysis involving successive hydrogenation and deoxygenation limits the development of SACs with satisfactory performance. The design of atomically dispersed ensemble sites, such as dual- or tri-atom catalysts seen in other reactions, is proposed. These multi-atom configurations could mediate and potentially alter entire catalytic pathways, achieving heightened catalytic activity and selectivity for NH3 production and yielding high-value byproducts beyond NH3. (3) Exploration of alternative routes: the challenges faced by N2-to-NH3 due to low solubility and high dissociation energy of molecular N2 and the questioned viability of NO x -to-NH3 due to low NO x concentrations in polluted water and flue gas call for exploration of alternative routes. Electrolytic routes coupled with N2 plasma, wherein reactive nitrogen species are efficiently converted to NH3, show promise. Unlike traditional methods, this approach utilizes highly concentrated NO x as an NH3 precursor in laboratory settings. (4) In-situ and Operando technologies: acknowledging the dynamic nature of active centers during real reaction conditions and recognizing that as-prepared catalysts are precursors, integrating in-situ and operando technologies becomes imperative. Techniques such as Raman, XAFS, IR, and Mössbauer spectra should be widely employed during actual catalysis processes to unveil dynamic catalytic processes and identify genuine active structures. This approach enhances our ability to comprehend and optimize catalytic systems for nitrogen conversion reactions. References 1 S.L. Foster S.I.P. Bakovic R.D. Duda S. Maheshwari R.D. Milton S.D. Gunji, W. Zhang, X. Zhao, W. L. Xu, Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A., 2023, 120, e2301011120. Jian-Feng Li is a full Professor of Chemistry at Xiamen University. He received his Bachelor's degree in Chemistry from Zhejiang University in 2003 and his Ph.D. degree in Chemistry from Xiamen University in 2010. He worked as a post-doctor at the University of Bern and ETH Zurich in Switzerland from 2011 to 2014. Professor Li's research interests include plasmonic core shell nanostructures, surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy, electrochemistry, and surface catalysis. He has published more than 240 peer-reviewed papers with a total citation of over 15000, including Nature, Nature Energy, Nature Mater., Nature Nanotechnol., Nature Catal., Chem. Rev., etc. He is a Senior Editor of J. Phys. Chem. A/B/C. Ji Yang graduated with a Ph.D. from Xiamen University in 2022. He carried out postdoctoral research in Jian-Feng Li's group at Xiamen University from 2022 to 2024. His study focuses on the structural evolution of single-atom catalysts under electrocatalytic process by employing in-situ/operando Raman/XAFS characterizations. He has published more than 26 peer-reviewed papers.

coredata.dc:description: Ammonia, a feedstock platform for fertilizer and pharmaceutical production, is regarded as a zero-carbon energy carrier. The electrochemical synthesis of ammonia, powered by clean and renewable electricity, has garnered increased attention as an alternative to the Haber-Bosch process. Very recently, single-atom catalysts (SACs) have become highly effective electrocatalysts for such electrochemical transformation, where the isolated metal sites ensure the high atomic utilization efficiency as well as the prevention of nitrogen-nitrogen coupling. In this review, we focus on the recent progress of single-atom catalysts in electrochemical ammonia synthesis and briefly introduce nitrogen cycles in both natural and artificial ecosystems, followed by a discussion of catalyst design by theoretical and experimental methods. Synthesis routes from different nitrogen sources, including dinitrogen (N2) and nitrogen oxides (NO x ), are also highlighted. Besides, the catalysis dynamics as an indispensable section is presented and discussed in-depth. Finally, we tackle challenges and offer perspectives, aspiring to provide insightful guidance for researchers in this community striving for advanced ammonia electrosynthesis.
